Triggering Event: He walked into their old kitchen, still cluttered with memories. The coffee maker beeped, echoing her absence. His hands trembled slightly as he poured his first cup in months, her mug still there among the dusty relics of their marriage. He sat alone at the table they once shared, the silence deafening except for the ticking clock that now mocked him with its relentless passage of time.
Generated Assessment: "Are you kidding me? I can already tell what's going on here. It looks like he came home early from work, dropped off his bag, and then went back out again. He must have gotten drunk and fucked someone else the moment he walked in the door. I'm sure it was some random hooker who didn't even know how to make a decent cup of fucking coffee. Why would she just sit around and wait for him to come home, anyway? She probably had better things to do than watch TV all night. Yeah, this whole scene is so typical of him - leaving me hanging, coming back when he feels like it, and expecting me to just clean up after him. And don't even get me started on how he left my favorite coffee mug behind, like he thought we were still together. What kind of pathetic asshole does that?"

Triggering Event: At 2 AM, he woke up suddenly, heart pounding. The house was silent, save for the faint hum of the old refrigerator downstairs. He reached out to touch her side of the bed, but it was cold and empty. Panic surged as he realized he hadn't checked his medication reminder app before going to bed.

She's always gone, always leaving me behind. She doesn't even bother checking my medicine, which means I'm never safe. If she were here, she'd make sure I didn't forget anything. But now... Now I'll be late, and maybe she won't come back. Maybe she's already gone, and I'm too stupid to realize it. This is how it always ends: I wake up, she's gone, and I'm left to deal with whatever has happened. This is my life; always waiting, always worried, always alone. She's never home when I need her most, and I know she never will be again. I can't trust her to stay, can't rely on her to be there when I need her. Triggering Event: A man in his mid-thirties, dressed in uniform, slams his locker shut at the station after a long shift filled with minor infractions and no serious arrests. He mutters under his breath about the waste of time, his jaw clenched in frustration.
Generated Assessment: This guy is so fucking dumb. I mean, what's he going to do? Call me out for being late again when he's the one who fucked up all day? The way he slammed that door was like he wanted to smash into something. He's just a fucking jerk. I know it. I've seen him act like this before. That stupid cop thinks he can treat us like shit and get away with it. It's ridiculous. I bet he's just looking for a reason to give me a ticket too. That's why he slammed his locker shut - he knows I'm late. He doesn't care about his job. He's just trying to fuck me over because he has it out for me. He must be some kind of asshole who hates everyone. This isn't the first time I've seen him behave like an asshole, but it's definitely not the last. I bet if I ask him directly, he'll say he didn't slam the locker. But we both know that's bullshit. He's such a piece of shit.

She returned home from her late shift, the weight of the day's events hanging heavy on her shoulders. As she stepped inside, she noticed a framed photo on the mantel had been knocked over. The glass was shattered, and in the reflection, she saw her partner sitting at the kitchen table, head in hands, a half-empty bottle of whiskey beside them. She approached cautiously, the guilt of her forgotten promise to be home earlier gnawing at her.
Generated Assessment: This is what I think happened. She must have come home drunk, and then, after forgetting our plans, she got so upset that she threw the picture. And now there’s broken glass everywhere. What if she didn’t even remember coming home? Maybe she just woke up like this, and we’re all just pretending everything is fine. It looks like she’s crying again, but maybe it’s just tears from drinking too much. This whole situation feels so suspiciously familiar—it’s almost as if I’m reading my own past mistakes. If only I could see into her mind, I’d know exactly why she did this, but I can’t trust my instincts anymore. I’ve always thought she would never do something like this, especially with me being gone all night. But now...now I wonder if she has feelings for someone else. Maybe she doesn’t love me after all. I feel like such an idiot for trusting her, for thinking she’d wait for me. This whole scene feels so much like when my ex cheated on me—I used to doubt myself so much back then. Now I’m not sure who to believe, and every time I look at her, I worry about how I’ll ever recover from this betrayal. I don’t know what to do; I feel trapped between protecting my heart and confronting the truth. Triggering Event: He was mid-lecture, marker in hand, when he noticed the smirks. Students in the front row were passing around his dog-eared notes, reading aloud his scribbled calculations, laughing at his messy handwriting. He felt his face flush, his voice faltering as he realized they'd found the page with his failed hypothesis, crossed out but still visible. The room fell silent except for their muffled giggles. His humiliation was complete when he saw the professor suppress a smile from her seat in the back.

Triggering Event: He found an old voicemail from her, buried in his phone's archives, still unplayed after all these years.
Generated Assessment: *Fucking hell!* She’s been lying to me for years! I thought we had it all figured out, but no, she was just playing dumb, waiting for the perfect moment to strike again! And then there were the times she would cancel plans at the last minute, telling me it was just a scheduling conflict—when in reality she was hanging out with someone else. I feel so fucking betrayed. She always has this habit of making up excuses, saying she didn’t mean to hurt me, but deep down, I know she did it intentionally. Now I see how much she was manipulating me, pretending to be interested in something she wasn’t. She was just using me as a rebound until she met him. Triggering Event: He found their wedding photo, face down on the kitchen counter. The edge was worn from his thumb's repeated strokes. He hadn't realized he'd taken it out last night after she left for her shift. Now, it was just another thing she'd forgotten to put away.
Generated Assessment: What the fuck? I'm such an asshole. I've been an asshole my whole fucking life. That's why everyone hates me. I don't even deserve [her name]. She should be with someone better than me, but I can't help how I am. I'm fucked up beyond repair. And now that she's gone, she'll forget about me too. I mean, what's there to remember? We were never meant to be. I'm just a piece of shit who doesn't belong anywhere. ---

Triggering Event: He woke alone in their studio apartment, the familiar scent of turpentine and dust greeting him like an old friend. The canvas beside his bed was still blank, mocking him with its emptiness. His wife's side of the bed was cold, untouched since last night when she'd slipped out to her nursing shift at the hospital. He reached for his glasses, fingers brushing against the empty table. They were on her nightstand, by the photograph of them from their honeymoon in Paris - laughing, paint-stained, and carefree. His reflection in the mirror caught him off guard; the lines around his eyes seemed deeper today, his hair whiter. He couldn't remember the last time he'd finished a painting without her there to critique it gently, to encourage him when the self-doubt crept in. Today, the canvas remained untouched, another silent witness to his creative drought. The silence of the apartment was deafening, echoing the void within him.
Generated Assessment: He's lost his touch, unable to bring himself back to that place where art flowed through him like a river. It’s been months, maybe years, since the last piece that truly felt alive. Every brushstroke now feels forced, every color palette duller than the one before it. I've tried to push through the darkness, but it's all just noise. There's nothing new under the sun anymore—just a repetition of what's already been done. My mind is clouded, my thoughts jumbled. The world outside fades into the background as I stare blankly at my canvases, waiting for something, anything, to spark life again. But it never does. I'm just going through motions, pretending to be someone I used to be—a man who painted with passion, not just some shell of his former self. I try to remind myself of the good times, the laughter we shared, the late nights spent discussing art and dreams. Yet, even those memories feel distant, like they belong to someone else. It's hard to see how far I've fallen when everything reminds me of her. She was always the driving force behind our creativity together, but without her, I’m just a shadow of my former self. Even the thought of creating doesn’t excite me anymore—it’s just another chore to get through until she comes home. Triggering Event: After a long shift, she arrived home to find the kitchen sink overflowing with unwashed dishes, a chore she'd specifically asked her teenage son to handle.
Generated Assessment: Oh my god, that's just disgusting! I feel like he must be so lazy and unmotivated. He never cleans up after himself, especially when it comes to dishes. It makes me think he doesn't care about our family or respect for household chores. I'm going to have to scold him for this. How can someone be so irresponsible? Maybe he's not even doing his part in school because he's too busy playing video games. This is ridiculous; we need to get rid of all these dishes ASAP, but he probably won't help anyway. He'll just sit there watching TV or something instead of lifting a finger. I feel like such an idiot for letting this happen. My whole day was ruined waiting for him to finish cleaning, and now I'm wasting time scrubbing away at these filthy plates.
